title.narrative: SWE-2010-194 Assessment of carbon sequestering capacity in East African seagrass ecosystems affected by multiple stressors in a changing climate
SWE-2010-194 Assessment of carbon sequestering capacity in East African seagrass ecosystems affected by multiple stressors in a changing climate

description.narrative: Seagrass meadows have a greater capacity to trap carbon than land carbon sinks. Thus, these ecosystems are essential to combating global warming. However, while the role of forests and peatlands in carbon sequestration has been well documented, surprisingly little has been made on the role that coastal habitats play in storing carbon. The project aims to evaluate the carbon sequestering efficiency in tropical seagrass meadows in the western Indian Ocean, in cooperation with Tanzanian Scientists. Also, we will study what effects stressors related to global warming has on this capacity and the overall primary production of these systems, and develop a predictive tool for future scenario modelling of carbon sequestration dynamics. We intend to combine experimental in situ surveys testing how plant productivity is affected with different levels of light, temperatures and carbon fluxes.

Seagrass meadows have a greater capacity to trap carbon than land carbon sinks. Thus, these ecosystems are essential to combating global warming. However, while the role of forests and peatlands in carbon sequestration has been well documented, surprisingly little has been made on the role that coastal habitats play in storing carbon. The project aims to evaluate the carbon sequestering efficiency in tropical seagrass meadows in the western Indian Ocean, in cooperation with Tanzanian Scientists. Also, we will study what effects stressors related to global warming has on this capacity and the overall primary production of these systems, and develop a predictive tool for future scenario modelling of carbon sequestration dynamics. We intend to combine experimental in situ surveys testing how plant productivity is affected with different levels of light, temperatures and carbon fluxes.

participating-org.narrative: University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank
